bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, March 30, 1928

div1.p: Kean sends Agramonte a photograph of Reed's birthplace and tells him that prior to Reed's birth his parent's home burned down. Kean congratulates Agramonte on the honors he received at a meeting in New Orleans. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, March 30, 1928
div1.opener:
Dr Aristides Agramonte
30 March, 1928.
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
Calle K, Entre 15 Y 17
Vedado, Habana.
My dear Dr. Agramonte:
div1.p:
I am greatly pleased to get your letter of the 20th, and to
have your much appreciated compliments on my address at the dedication
of Major Reed's birthplace.

I am sending you herewith a photograph of the little house.
The story is that just before his birth the house in which his parents
were living was burned and they had to move into this little cabin with
two rooms until the dwelling house could be rebuilt. This explains
the very modest size and appearance of his birthplace. It is perhaps
fortunate for the Virginia Medical Society that it was so, because if
it had been a big house they would not have had the money to buy it.

I was very glad to read in the medical journals an account of
the honors that you received at the meeting in New Orleans. I also had
mention of it in a letter from Dr. John B. Elliott of New Orleans. It
just shows that all things come to those who wait.
div1.closer:
With cordial regards, I am
Sincerely yours, J.R. KEAN, Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.
